p: The ethanolic and acetone extracts of the leaves of Lippia javanica and the ethyl acetate extract of the bark of Pterocarpus angolensis both had MICs of 90 μg/ml for Campylobacter spp. These were described for the first time as effective against Campylobacter spp. in 2009 [ 33]. These plants are used in the Venda region of South Africa for treatment of several diseases. L. javanica leaves are used for treatment of asthma, malaria, and diarrhea. A decoction or infusion of root or leaves is taken orally to treat diarrhea [ 43]. Other traditional medicinal uses of the plant in Africa are to treat bronchitis, chest pains, wounds, fever/malaria, cough, and colds, as well as to repel mosquitoes [ 43].
